 नामाध्यायो दशमः CK82K10K07; नाम दशमो ऽध्यायः E



[ ekādaśamo 'dhyāyaḥ ] [ एकादशमो ऽध्यायः ] [ caturāśramadharmavidhānaḥ ] [ चतुराश्रमधर्मविधानः ]
devy uvāca | देव्युवाच ।
sarvayajñaḥ paraśreṣṭha asti anyaḥ surottama | सर्वयज्ञः परश्रेष्ठ अस्ति अन्यः सुरोत्तम ।
1b anyaḥ C45K82K07; anya C94C02K10, cānyā E •
 १ b: अन्यः C45K82K07; अन्य C94C02K10, चान्या E •
 °ttama CK82K10E; °ttamaḥ K07
 °त्तम CK82K10E; °त्तमः K07
Testimonia for this chapter: C94 ff. 208v–210r, C45 ff. 214r–215v, C02 ff. 285v–287v, K82 ff. 15v–17v, K10 ff. 221v–223v (exp. 56 lower – 58 lower), K07 ff. 223v–225v; E pp. 613–617; C = C94 + C45 + C02
alpakleśa-m-anāyāsa arthaprāyaṃ vineśvara ||11.1|| अल्पक्लेशमनायास अर्थप्रायं विनेश्वर ॥११:१
1c °nāyāsa CK07E; °nāyā≀saṃ≀ K82, °≀nāyā≀saṃ K10
 १ c: °नायास CK07E; °नाया≀सं≀ K82, °≀नाया≀सं K10
 1d °rthaprāyaṃ K82pcK07; °rthaprāya C, १ d: °र्थप्रायं K82pcK07; °र्थप्राय C, °rthaprārthaprāyaṃ K82ac, °≀rthaprāya≀ K10, °thāmnāya E •
 °र्थप्रार्थप्रायं K82ac, °≀र्थप्राय≀ K10, °थाम्नाय E •
 vineśvara CK82K07; ≀vineśvara≀ K10, sureśvara E
 विनेश्वर CK82K07; ≀विनेश्वर≀ K10, सुरेश्वर E
sarvayajñaphalāvāpti daivataiś cāpi pūjitam | सर्वयज्ञफलावाप्ति दैवतैश्चापि पूजितम् ।
2a daivatai° C94C45K82E; devatai° C02K07, ≀devatai≀ K10
 २ a: दैवतै° C94C45K82E; देवतै° C02K07, ≀देवतै≀ K10
kathayasva suraśreṣṭha mānuṣāṇāṃ hitāya vai ||11.2|| कथयस्व सुरश्रेष्ठ मानुषाणां हिताय वै ॥११:२
2cd °śreṣṭha mānuṣāṇāṃ hitāya vai CK82K07E; °śre×××××××××× K10
 २ cd: °श्रेष्ठ मानुषाणां हिताय वै CK82K07E; °श्रे×××××××××× K10
maheśvara uvāca | महेश्वर उवाच ।
3 mahe° CK82K10E; mehe° K07
 3: महे° CK82K10E; मेहे° K07
na tulyaṃ tava paśyāmi dayā bhūteṣu bhāmini | न तुल्यं तव पश्यामि दया भूतेषु भामिनि ।
3a tulyaṃ tava K82C45C02K10K07E; ×××× C94
 ३ a: तुल्यं तव K82C45C02K10K07E; ×××× C94
 3b bhāmini C94C45K82K10K07E; bhāmi C02
 ३ b: भामिनि C94C45K82K10K07E; भामि C02
kim anyat kathayiṣyāmi dayā yatra na vidyate ||11.3|| किमन्यत्कथयिष्यामि दया यत्र न विद्यते ॥११:३
3c kim anya° CK82K07E; kimyanya° K10
 ३ c: किमन्य° CK82K07E; किम्यन्य° K10
sadāśivamukhāt pūrvaṃ śrutaṃ me varasundari | सदाशिवमुखात्पूर्वं श्रुतं मे वरसुन्दरि ।
śṛṇu devi pravakṣyāmi dharmasāram anuttamam ||11.4|| शृणु देवि प्रवक्ष्यामि धर्मसारमनुत्तमम् ॥११:४

[ gṛhasthaḥ(?) ] [ गृहस्थः(?) ]
vinārthena tu yo yajñaḥ sa yajñaḥ sārvakāmikaḥ | विनार्थेन तु यो यज्ञः स यज्ञः सार्वकामिकः ।
5b yajñaḥ CK82K10K07; yajña E •
 ५ b: यज्ञः CK82K10K07; यज्ञ E •

5ab See a sequence or list of the four āśramas in 4.75 above: gṛhastho brahmacārī ca vānaprastho 'tha bhaikṣukaḥ; see also 5.9: etac chaucaṃ gṛhasthānāṃ dviguṇaṃ brahmacāriṇām| vānaprasthasya triguṇaṃ yatīnāṃ tu caturguṇam||
akṣayaś cāvyayaś caiva sarvapātakanāśanaḥ ||11.5|| अक्षयश्चाव्ययश्चैव सर्वपातकनाशनः ॥११:५

pañcaśodhyena śodhyeta arthayajño varānane | पञ्चशोध्येन शोध्येत अर्थयज्ञो वरानने ।
7b °yajño C94C45K82K10K07E; °yajña C02
 ७ b: °यज्ञो C94C45K82K10K07E; °यज्ञ C02
śodhite tu phalaṃ śuddham aśuddhe niṣphalaṃ bhavet ||11.7|| शोधिते तु फलं शुद्धमशुद्धे निष्फलं भवेत् ॥११:७

pañcaśodhye suraśreṣṭha saṃśayo 'tra bhaven mama | पञ्चशोध्ये सुरश्रेष्ठ संशयो ऽत्र भवेन्मम ।

 ८ b: ऽत्र भवे° CK82K10K07; ऽत्रा भव° E
kathayasva vibhāgena śrotum icchāmi tattvataḥ ||11.8|| कथयस्व विभागेन श्रोतुमिच्छामि तत्त्वतः ॥११:८
rudra uvāca | रुद्र उवाच ।
manaḥśuddhis tu prathamaṃ dravyaśuddhir ataḥ param | मनःशुद्धिस्तु प्रथमं द्रव्यशुद्धिरतः परम् ।
9b °śuddhir ataḥ CK82K07E; °śuddhigataḥ K10
 ९ b: °शुद्धिरतः CK82K07E; °शुद्धिगतः K10
mantraśuddhis tṛtīyā tu karmaśuddhir ataḥ param | मन्त्रशुद्धिस्तृतीया तु कर्मशुद्धिरतः परम् ।
9a mantraśuddhis tṛtīyā CK82K10E; mantraddhi tṛtīyā K07
 ९ a: मन्त्रशुद्धिस्तृतीया CK82K10E; मन्त्रद्धि तृतीया K07
 9b karmaśuddhi° CK82K10E; karmasiddhi K07
 ९ b: कर्मशुद्धि° CK82K10E; कर्मसिद्धि K07
pañcamī sattvaśuddhis tu kratuśuddhiś ca pañcadhā ||11.9|| पञ्चमी सत्त्वशुद्धिस्तु क्रतुशुद्धिश्च पञ्चधा ॥११:९

āśramaḥ prathamas tubhyaṃ kathito 'sti varānane | आश्रमः प्रथमस्तुभ्यं कथितो ऽस्ति वरानने ।
25a āśramaḥ C94K82K10K07E; āśrama C45C02 •
 २५ a: आश्रमः C94K82K10K07E; आश्रम C45C02 •

 २५ b: ऽस्ति C94C45K82K07; स्मि C02K10E
sadāśivena saddharmaṃ daivatair api pūjitam ||11.25|| सदाशिवेन सद्धर्मं दैवतैरपि पूजितम् ॥११:२५

[ brahmacārī ] [ ब्रह्मचारी ]
brahmacaryaṃ nibodhedaṃ śṛṇuṣvāvahitā śubhe | ब्रह्मचर्यं निबोधेदं शृणुष्वावहिता शुभे ।
26a °caryaṃ CK10K07E; °carya K82
 २६ a: °चर्यं CK10K07E; °चर्य K82
 26b °vahitā śubhe C94C45K82K07E; °vahito bhava C02, °vahito śubhe K10
 २६ b: °वहिता शुभे C94C45K82K07E; °वहितो भव C02, °वहितो शुभे K10
dvitīyam āśramaṃ devi sarvapāpavināśanam ||11.26|| द्वितीयमाश्रमं देवि सर्वपापविनाशनम् ॥११:२६
26d °vināśanam CK82K07E; °pranāśanam K10
 २६ d: °विनाशनम् CK82K07E; °प्रनाशनम् K10
26cd cf. MBH 12.184.10A: gārhasthyaṃ khalu dvitīyam āśramaṃ vadanti
vrataṃ brahmaparaṃ dhyānaṃ sāvitrī prakṛti-r-layam | व्रतं ब्रह्मपरं ध्यानं सावित्री प्रकृतिर्लयम् ।
27a °paraṃ dhyānaṃ CK82K10K07; °parijñānaṃ E

27ab cf. VSS 16.8cd

dama daṇḍa dayā pātraṃ bhikṣā saṃsāramocanam | दम दण्ड दया पात्रं भिक्षा संसारमोचनम् ।

 41f °prasthaś ca° C94C45K82K07E; °prastha ca° C02K10
 ४१ f: °प्रस्थश्च° C94C45K82K07E; °प्रस्थ च° C02K10
vānaprastham ayaṃ dharmaṃ gadita yat pūrvam avadhāritaṃ वानप्रस्थमयं धर्मं गदित यत्पूर्वमवधारितं
42a gadita yat pūrvam avadhāritam conj.; gaditaṃ pūrvadhāritam C94C45, ४२ a: गदित यत् पूर्वम् अवधारितम् conj.; गदितं पूर्वधारितम् C94C45, yat pūrvam avadhāritaṃ C02E, यत्पूर्वमवधारितं C02E, gadita pūrvadhāritaṃ K10, गदित पूर्वधारितं K10, gaditaṃ yat pūrvadhāritaṃ K82ac, गदितं यत्पूर्वधारितं K82ac, gaditaṃ yat pūrva≀m avadhā≀ritaṃ K82pc, गदितं यत्पूर्व≀मवधा≀रितं K82pc, gaditaṃ yat pūrvamedhāritaṃ K07
 गदितं यत्पूर्वमेधारितं K07
     saṃsāroddharaṇam anityaharaṇam ajñānanirmūlanam |     संसारोद्धरणमनित्यहरणमज्ञाननिर्मूलनम् ।

[ parivrājakaḥ ] [ परिव्राजकः ]
parivrājakadharmo 'yaṃ kīrtayiṣyāmi tac chṛṇu | परिव्राजकधर्मो ऽयं कीर्तयिष्यामि तच्छृणु ।
43b kīrtayiṣyāmi C45C02K82K10K07E; kīrtayi×mi C94
 ४३ b: कीर्तयिष्यामि C45C02K82K10K07E; कीर्तयि×मि C94
sukhaduḥkhaṃ samaṃ kṛtvā lobhamohavivarjitaḥ ||11.43|| सुखदुःखं समं कृत्वा लोभमोहविवर्जितः ॥११:४३
43c °duḥkhaṃ C45; °duḥkha C94C02K82K10K07E

 °varjitaḥ CK82K07E; °varjitāḥ K10
 °वर्जितः CK82K07E; °वर्जिताः K10
43d cf. VSS 4.71: kāmaḥ krodhaś ca lobhaś ca mohaś caiva caturvidhaḥ| catuḥśatrur nihantavyaḥ sarvathā vītakalmaṣaḥ||
varjayen madhu māṃsāni paradārāṃś ca varjayet | वर्जयेन्मधु मांसानि परदारांश्च वर्जयेत् ।
44a varjayen C94K10; varjayet C45C02K82K07E
 ४४ a: वर्जयेन् C94K10; वर्जयेत् C45C02K82K07E

varjayec ciravāsaṃ ca paravāsaṃ ca varjayet ||11.44|| वर्जयेच्चिरवासं च परवासं च वर्जयेत् ॥११:४४

varjayet saṃgrahaṃ nityam abhimānaṃ ca varjayet ||11.45|| वर्जयेत्संग्रहं नित्यमभिमानं च वर्जयेत् ॥११:४५
susūkṣmaṃ manasā dhyātvā dṛśau pādaṃ vinikṣipet | सुसूक्ष्मं मनसा ध्यात्वा दृशौ पादं विनिक्षिपेत् ।

na cāsīta na tiṣṭheta na ca dehīti vā vadet ||11.51|| न चासीत न तिष्ठेत न च देहीति वा वदेत् ॥११:५१

karuṇāvartacakreṇa krodhamattagajaṃ jayet | करुणावर्तचक्रेण क्रोधमत्तगजं जयेत् ।
muditāvarmabaddhāṅgas tūṇaṃ pūrṇam upekṣayā ||11.56|| मुदितावर्मबद्धाङ्गस्तूणं पूर्णमुपेक्षया ॥११:५६
56f tūṇaṃ pūrṇam u° em. Goodall; tūṇṇāpūrṇṇam u° C94, ५६ f: तूणं पूर्णमु° em. Goodall; तूण्णापूर्ण्णमु° C94, tūṇāpūrṇṇam u° C45, tū≀na≀pūrṇṇam u° C02, तूणापूर्ण्णमु° C45, तू≀न≀पूर्ण्णमु° C02, tūṇṇāpūṇṇām u° K82, tūrṇṇāpūrṇṇam u° K10K07, tūṇīpūrṇam u° E

anakṣaraṃ paraṃ brahma cintayet satataṃ dvija | अनक्षरं परं ब्रह्म चिन्तयेत्सततं द्विज ।
57a anakṣaraṃ C45; anākṣaraṃ C94K82, anākṣara° C02K07E, anakṣara° K10 •

brahmaṇo hṛdayaṃ viṣṇur viṣṇoś ca hṛdayaṃ śivaḥ | ब्रह्मणो हृदयं विष्णुर्विष्णोश्च हृदयं शिवः ।
57c hṛdayaṃ C45C02K82K10E; ×dayaṃ C94, hṛdaye K07
 ५७ c: हृदयं C45C02K82K10E; ×दयं C94, हृदये K07

 57d śivaḥ E; śivaṃ CK82K10K07
 ५७ d: शिवः E; शिवं CK82K10K07
śivasya hṛdayaṃ saṃdhyā tasmāt saṃdhyām upāsayet ||11.57|| शिवस्य हृदयं संध्या तस्मात्संध्यामुपासयेत् ॥११:५७
57d °sayet C94C02K10; °śayet C45K82, °śrayet K07E
 ५७ d: °सयेत् C94C02K10; °शयेत् C45K82, °श्रयेत् K07E
57 ≈ Saubhāgyabhāskara of Bhāskararāya ad Lalitāsahasranāmastotra 302: brahmaṇo hṛdayaṃ viṣṇur viṣṇor api śivaḥ smṛtaḥ| śivasya hṛdayaṃ sandhyā tenopāsyā dvijātibhiḥ|| iti kaśyapādivacanaiḥ kaurmapādmaskāndādinikhilapurāṇeṣu ca tatra tatra devīkālikābrahmāṇḍamārkaṇḍeyādipurāṇeṣu bahuśaḥ śaktirahasya-devībhāgavata-tṛtīyaskandhādiṣu ca idaṃparyeṇa sarvatra jñānārṇavakulārṇavāditantreṣu tv aparimitatyā varṇitam
saṃsārārṇavatāraṇaṃ śubhagatiḥ sa brahma saṃdhyākṣaraṃ संसारार्णवतारणं शुभगतिः स ब्रह्म संध्याक्षरं

     dhyāyen nityam atandrito hy anupamaṃ vyaktātmavedyaṃ śivam |     ध्यायेन्नित्यमतन्द्रितो ह्यनुपमं व्यक्तात्मवेद्यं शिवम् ।

     || iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe caturāśramadharmavidhāno nāmādhyāya ekādaśamaḥ ||      इति वृषसारसंग्रहे चतुराश्रमधर्मविधानो नामाध्याय एकादशमः ॥

 नाम एकादशो ऽध्यायः E



[ dvādaśamo 'dhyāyaḥ ] [ द्वादशमो ऽध्यायः ] [ ātithyadharmaḥ ] [ आतिथ्यधर्मः ]
devy uvāca | देव्युवाच ।
ahiṃsā paramo dharmaḥ satataṃ parikīrtyate | अहिंसा परमो धर्मः सततं परिकीर्त्यते ।
1ab dharmaḥ sa° C94C45K82K10K07E; dharmos sa° C02
 १ ab: धर्मः स° C94C45K82K10K07E; धर्मोस्स° C02
Testimonia for this chapter: C94 ff. 210r–215r, C45 ff. 215v–219v, C02 ff. 287v–283v (f. 291 is missing), K82 ff. 17v–22r, K10 exp. 58 (lower) – 62 (lower), K07 ff. 225v–230r, E pp. 617–628; C = C94 + C45 + C02
ātithyakānāṃ dharmaṃ ca kathayasva yad uttamam ||12.1|| आतिथ्यकानां धर्मं च कथयस्व यदुत्तमम् ॥१२:१
1c ātithya° C94C02K82K07E; atithya° C45K10 •
 १ c: आतिथ्य° C94C02K82K07E; अतिथ्य° C45K10 •
 dharmaṃ ca C94C45K82K07E; dharmaś ca C02, dharmānāṃ K10
 धर्मं च C94C45K82K07E; धर्मश्च C02, धर्मानां K10
maheśvara uvāca | महेश्वर उवाच ।
2 maheśvara CK10K07E; bhagavān K82
 2: महेश्वर CK10K07E; भगवान् K82
ahiṃsātithyakānāṃ ca śṛṇu dharmaṃ yad uttamam | अहिंसातिथ्यकानां च शृणु धर्मं यदुत्तमम् ।
2b śṛṇu C45C02K82K10K07E; ×ṇu C94 •

trailokyam akhilaṃ devi ratnapūrṇaṃ sulocane ||12.2|| त्रैलोक्यमखिलं देवि रत्नपूर्णं सुलोचने ॥१२:२
2d °pūrṇaṃ C94C45K82K10K07; pūrṇṇa C02, °pūrṇāṃ E •

caturvedavide dānaṃ na tattulyam ahiṃsakaḥ | चतुर्वेदविदे दानं न तत्तुल्यमहिंसकः ।
3a dānaṃ C94C02K82K10K07E; nānaṃ C45
 ३ a: दानं C94C02K82K10K07E; नानं C45
śṛṇu dharmam atithyānāṃ kīrtayiṣyāmi sundari ||12.3|| शृणु धर्ममतिथ्यानां कीर्तयिष्यामि सुन्दरि ॥१२:३
[ vipulopākhyānam ] [ विपुलोपाख्यानम् ]
āsīd vṛttaṃ purākhyānaṃ nagare kusumāhvaye | आसीद्वृत्तं पुराख्यानं नगरे कुसुमाह्वये ।

kapilasya suto vidvān vipulo nāma viśrutaḥ ||12.4|| कपिलस्य सुतो विद्वान्विपुलो नाम विश्रुतः ॥१२:४
dharmanityo jitakrodhaḥ satyavādī jitendriyaḥ | धर्मनित्यो जितक्रोधः सत्यवादी जितेन्द्रियः ।

 १२ d: °भूषणः C94C45K10K07E; °भूष≀णैः≀ C02, °भूषितः K82
devatāguruviprāṇām anyeṣāṃ tarpaṇe rataḥ | देवतागुरुविप्राणामन्येषां तर्पणे रतः ।
13ab devatāguruviprāṇām anyeṣāṃ tarpaṇe rataḥ C45K82pcK10K07; १३ ab: देवतागुरुविप्राणामन्येषां तर्पणे रतः C45K82pcK10K07; devatāguruvi×ṇām anyeṣāṃ tarpaṇe rataḥ C94, देवतागुरुवि×णामन्येषां तर्पणे रतः C94, devatāguruviprāṇām anyeṣāṃ tarpaṇe ratāḥ C02, देवतागुरुविप्राणामन्येषां तर्पणे रताः C02, omitted in K82ac, omitted in K82ac, devatāguruviprāṇām anyeṣāṃ tarpaṇā rataḥ E

tatrāvasarasamprāpto brāhmaṇo 'tithir āgataḥ ||12.13|| तत्रावसरसम्प्राप्तो ब्राह्मणो ऽतिथिरागतः ॥१२:१३
bhāryā tasyātirūpeṇa mohitā brahmaṇas tadā | भार्या तस्यातिरूपेण मोहिता ब्रह्मणस्तदा ।
14b mohitā C94C02K82K10K07E; mohito C45 •
 १४ b: मोहिता C94C02K82K10K07E; मोहितो C45 •

brāhmaṇo 'pi tathaiveha rūpeṇāpratimo bhavet ||12.14|| ब्राह्मणो ऽपि तथैवेह रूपेणाप्रतिमो भवेत् ॥१२:१४
14c brāhmaṇo C94C02K82K10K07E; brahmaṇo C45 •

anyonyadṛṣṭisaṃsaktau jātau tau tu parasparam | अन्योन्यदृष्टिसंसक्तौ जातौ तौ तु परस्परम् ।
15a °saṃsaktau E; °saṃśaktau C94K82K07, °śaktau C45, °saṃsakto C02K10

vipulenāñjaliṃ kṛtvā brāhmaṇa saṃśitavrata ||12.15|| विपुलेनाञ्जलिं कृत्वा ब्राह्मण संशितव्रत ॥१२:१५

ājñāpaya dvijaśreṣṭha adya me 'nugrahaṃ kuru | आज्ञापय द्विजश्रेष्ठ अद्य मे ऽनुग्रहं कुरु ।
16b °grahaṃ C94C02K82K10K07E; °graha C45
 १६ b: °ग्रहं C94C02K82K10K07E; °ग्रह C45

17b brāhmaṇo 'bravīt C94C45K82K10K07E; bhrāhmaṇas tathā C02

kulatrāṇāt kalatrāsmi bharaṇād bhārya eva ca ||12.28|| कुलत्राणात्कलत्रास्मि भरणाद्भार्य एव च ॥१२:२८

 २८ c: कुल° C45; कल° C94C02K82K10K07E •

dārasaṃgraha putrārthe kriyate śāstradarśanāt | दारसंग्रह पुत्रार्थे क्रियते शास्त्रदर्शनात् ।
29a °graha C02K10K07E; °grahaḥ C94C45K82 •
 २९ a: °ग्रह C02K10K07E; °ग्रहः C94C45K82 •

 २९ b: क्रियते C94C02K82K10K07E; क्रियाते C45
yāni santi gṛhe dravyaṃ grāmaghoṣagṛhāṇi ca ||12.29|| यानि सन्ति गृहे द्रव्यं ग्रामघोषगृहाणि च ॥१२:२९
dātum arhasi viprāya na māṃ dātum ihārhasi | दातुमर्हसि विप्राय न मां दातुमिहार्हसि ।
bhāryāyā vacanaṃ śrutvā vipulaḥ punar abravīt ||12.30|| भार्याया वचनं श्रुत्वा विपुलः पुनरब्रवीत् ॥१२:३०
30c vacanaṃ CK82K10E; vacana K07
 ३० c: वचनं CK82K10E; वचन K07

sādhu bhāmini jānāmi sādhu sādhu pativrate | साधु भामिनि जानामि साधु साधु पतिव्रते ।
31a jānāmi C45C02K82E; jānāsi C94K10K07
 ३१ a: जानामि C45C02K82E; जानासि C94K10K07

 ३१ b: पति° CK82K07E; प्रति° K10
jito 'smy anena vākyena anenāsmi hi toṣitaḥ ||12.31|| जितो ऽस्म्यनेन वाक्येन अनेनास्मि हि तोषितः ॥१२:३१
31d toṣitaḥ CK82K10E; torṣinaḥ K07
 ३१ d: तोषितः CK82K10E; तोर्षिनः K07
adya grahaṇakāle ca dvija āgatya yācate | अद्य ग्रहणकाले च द्विज आगत्य याचते ।
dadāmīti pratijñāya adattvā narakaṃ vraje ||12.32|| ददामीति प्रतिज्ञाय अदत्त्वा नरकं व्रजे ॥१२:३२
32d vraje C94K82pcK07; vrajet C45C02K10E, vraje* K82ac

narakaṃ yadi gacchāmi kulena saha sundari | नरकं यदि गच्छामि कुलेन सह सुन्दरि ।

kalpakoṭisahasre 'pi narakastho yaśasvini | कल्पकोटिसहस्रे ऽपि नरकस्थो यशस्विनि ।

muktim eva na paśyāmi janmakoṭiśatair api ||12.33|| मुक्तिमेव न पश्यामि जन्मकोटिशतैरपि ॥१२:३३

adānāc cāśubhaṃ devi paśyāmi varavarṇini | अदानाच्चाशुभं देवि पश्यामि वरवर्णिनि ।

dānena tu śubhaṃ paśye svargaloke yad akṣayam ||12.34|| दानेन तु शुभं पश्ये स्वर्गलोके यदक्षयम् ॥१२:३४

noktaṃ mayānṛtaṃ pūrvaṃ nityaṃ satyavrate sthitaḥ | नोक्तं मयानृतं पूर्वं नित्यं सत्यव्रते स्थितः ।

satyadharmam atikramya nānyadharmaṃ samācare ||12.35|| सत्यधर्ममतिक्रम्य नान्यधर्मं समाचरे ॥१२:३५
35d °care CK82K07; °caret K10E
 ३५ d: °चरे CK82K07; °चरेत् K10E
bhāryā dharmasakhety evaṃ tvayā pūrvam udāhṛtam | भार्या धर्मसखेत्येवं त्वया पूर्वमुदाहृतम् ।
36a dharma° CK10K07E; dharmaṃ K82
 ३६ a: धर्म° CK10K07E; धर्मं K82

yadi dharmasakhāyāsi so 'dya kāla ihāgataḥ ||12.36|| यदि धर्मसखायासि सो ऽद्य काल इहागतः ॥१२:३६
36c °sakhāyā° C94C02K82K10K07E; °sakhā° C45
 ३६ c: °सखाया° C94C02K82K10K07E; °सखा° C45
dvijarūpadharo dharmaḥ svayam eva ihāgataḥ | द्विजरूपधरो धर्मः स्वयमेव इहागतः ।
37a °dharo C94C02K82K10K07E; °paro C45
 ३७ a: °धरो C94C02K82K10K07E; °परो C45
jijñāsārtham ahaṃ bhadre na vighnaṃ kartum arhasi ||12.37|| जिज्ञासार्थमहं भद्रे न विघ्नं कर्तुमर्हसि ॥१२:३७
37c °rtham ahaṃ CK82E; °rthamm ahaṃ K10, °rtham aha K07

mātāvyaktaḥ pitā brahmā buddhir bhāryā damaḥ sakhā | माताव्यक्तः पिता ब्रह्मा बुद्धिर्भार्या दमः सखा ।

putro dharmaḥ kriyācārya ity ete mama bāndhavāḥ ||12.38|| पुत्रो धर्मः क्रियाचार्य इत्येते मम बान्धवाः ॥१२:३८
kālaśreṣṭho grahaḥ sūryo gaṅgā śreṣṭhā nadīṣu ca | कालश्रेष्ठो ग्रहः सूर्यो गङ्गा श्रेष्ठा नदीषु च ।

śuśrūṣaṇārthaṃ viprasya mayā dattāsi sundari | शुश्रूषणार्थं विप्रस्य मया दत्तासि सुन्दरि ।
40a °rthaṃ C94C02K82K10K07E; °rtha C45

vaset tatra gṛhe ramye bhāryām ādāya tasya ca | वसेत्तत्र गृहे रम्ये भार्यामादाय तस्य च ।

kva gacchāmi kva bhokṣyāmi kutra vā kiṃ karomy aham ||12.48|| क्व गच्छामि क्व भोक्ष्यामि कुत्र वा किं करोम्यहम् ॥१२:४८
48c kva gacchāmi CK82K10E; kṣa gacchāmi K07 •
 ४८ c: क्व गच्छामि CK82K10E; क्ष गच्छामि K07 •

na pathaṃ viṣayaṃ vedmi grāmaṃ vā nagarāṇi vā | न पथं विषयं वेद्मि ग्रामं वा नगराणि वा ।
49a viṣayaṃ vedmi C94K82K10E; viṣamaṃ vedmi C45C02, viyaṣaṃ ve≀śmi≀ K07

49c kheṭa° C94C45K82K10K07E; kṣetra° C02 •

tam āruhya nirīkṣyāmi grāmaṃ nagarapattanam ||12.50|| तमारुह्य निरीक्ष्यामि ग्रामं नगरपत्तनम् ॥१२:५०

apūrvaṃ ca surūpaṃ ca sugandhatvaṃ ca śobhanam ||12.52|| अपूर्वं च सुरूपं च सुगन्धत्वं च शोभनम् ॥१२:५२

vipulaś citravad dṛṣṭvā vismayaṃ paramaṃ gataḥ | विपुलश्चित्रवद्दृष्ट्वा विस्मयं परमं गतः ।
54a °travad dṛṣṭvā C94C45K82K10K07E; °trava dṛṣṭvā C02

aho vā svapnabhūto 'smi aho vā tapasaḥ phalam ||12.54|| अहो वा स्वप्नभूतो ऽस्मि अहो वा तपसः फलम् ॥१२:५४

na paśyāmi na jighrāmi na ca svādaṃ ca vedmy aham | न पश्यामि न जिघ्रामि न च स्वादं च वेद्म्यहम् ।

tat phalaṃ pratigṛhyaiva nagaraṃ praviśāmy aham | तत्फलं प्रतिगृह्यैव नगरं प्रविशाम्यहम् ।

 64d śreṣṭhikasya gṛhāgataḥ CK82K10K07; ६४ d: श्रेष्ठिकस्य गृहागतः CK82K10K07; śreṣṭhikasya gṛhāgataḥ|| pathiko 'ham idāniñ ca| श्रेष्ठिकस्य गृहागतः || पथिको ऽहमिदानिञ्च | ko bhavān tasya viṣaye kiṃ vā jñātuṃ cikīrṣasi|| E
 को भवान् तस्य विषये किं वा ज्ञातुं चिकीर्षसि || E
śreṣṭhikaḥ puṇḍako nāma khyātaḥ śreṣṭhika ucyate | श्रेष्ठिकः पुण्डको नाम ख्यातः श्रेष्ठिक उच्यते ।
kautukaṃ tava yady asti tad āgaccha mayā saha ||12.65|| कौतुकं तव यद्यस्ति तदागच्छ मया सह ॥१२:६५

aho phalam idaṃ śreṣṭham aho phalam ihānitam | अहो फलमिदं श्रेष्ठमहो फलमिहानितम् ।
68ab śreṣṭham aho C94C45K82K10K07E; śreṣṭha aho C02
 ६८ ab: श्रेष्ठमहो C94C45K82K10K07E; श्रेष्ठ अहो C02
aho rūpam aho gandha-m-aho phalaṃ suśobhanam ||12.68|| अहो रूपमहो गन्धमहो फलं सुशोभनम् ॥१२:६८
68cd gandham aho phalaṃ corr.; gandham aho phala C94C45pcC02K82E, ६८ cd: गन्धमहो फलं corr.; गन्धमहो फल C94C45pcC02K82E, gandham aho gandham aho phala C45ac, गन्धमहो गन्धमहो फल C45ac, gandha aho phala K10, gandho phalaṃ aho K07

tat phalaṃ na mahījātaṃ na merau na ca mandare | तत्फलं न महीजातं न मेरौ न च मन्दरे ।

aho 'smi sa phalaṃ bhoktā rājārhaṃ ca na saṃśayaḥ | अहो ऽस्मि स फलं भोक्ता राजार्हं च न संशयः ।

tatas tvarita gatvaiva phalaṃ gṛhya manoharam | ततस्त्वरित गत्वैव फलं गृह्य मनोहरम् ।

ādareṇopasṛtyaiva rājānaṃ sa phalaṃ dadau ||12.71|| आदरेणोपसृत्यैव राजानं स फलं ददौ ॥१२:७१

svādumūlaṃ phalaṃ kandaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ pūrvaṃ na tādṛśam | स्वादुमूलं फलं कन्दं दृष्टं पूर्वं न तादृशम् ।

rūpagandhaguṇopetaṃ hṛdayānandakārakam ||12.73|| रूपगन्धगुणोपेतं हृदयानन्दकारकम् ॥१२:७३

sadya evopayuñjāmi tvayā dattam idaṃ phalam | सद्य एवोपयुञ्जामि त्वया दत्तमिदं फलम् ।

yadi nāsti kiṃ me dattaṃ mayā vā mārgito bhavān | यदि नास्ति किं मे दत्तं मया वा मार्गितो भवान् ।
86a kiṃ me dattaṃ K07; kime dattaṃ CK82K10, kim etat taṃ E
 ८६ a: किं मे दत्तं K07; किमे दत्तं CK82K10, किमेतत्तं E

yatra hy eko bahavo 'tra jāyante nātra saṃśayaḥ ||12.86|| यत्र ह्येको बहवो ऽत्र जायन्ते नात्र संशयः ॥१२:८६

āgamopāyamārgaṃ ca tenaiva sa tu gamyatām | आगमोपायमार्गं च तेनैव स तु गम्यताम् ।

adattvā phalam anyac ca śiraś chedyāmi durmate | अदत्त्वा फलमन्यच्च शिरश्छेद्यामि दुर्मते ।
88a adattvā C94C45K82K07pcE; adattā K10, adatvāphatvā K07ac
 ८८ a: अदत्त्वा C94C45K82K07pcE; अदत्ता K10, अदत्वाफत्वा K07ac

tato bhīmabalaḥ kruddhaḥ khaḍgaṃ gṛhya śaśiprabham | ततो भीमबलः क्रुद्धः खड्गं गृह्य शशिप्रभम् ।

sadyo 'sti phalam anyad vā dehi rājānam adya vai ||12.90|| सद्यो ऽस्ति फलमन्यद्वा देहि राजानमद्य वै ॥१२:९०

yatra prāptaṃ phalaṃ divyaṃ tatra vādeśaya tvaram | यत्र प्राप्तं फलं दिव्यं तत्र वादेशय त्वरम् ।

tatphalena vinā bhadra durlabhaṃ tava jīvitam ||12.91|| तत्फलेन विना भद्र दुर्लभं तव जीवितम् ॥१२:९१
vipula uvāca | विपुल उवाच ।

tatra gacchāva bho śreṣṭhi dṛśyate yadi vānaraḥ | तत्र गच्छाव भो श्रेष्ठि दृश्यते यदि वानरः ।

104 gandharvarāja uvāca C45; gandharvarājovāca C94K10E, gandharvarājauvāca K82, 104: गन्धर्वराज उवाच C45; गन्धर्वराजोवाच C94K10E, गन्धर्वराजौवाच K82, gandharāja uvāca K07

sūryalokagataś cāsmi tena dattaṃ phalottamam | सूर्यलोकगतश्चास्मि तेन दत्तं फलोत्तमम् ।
104a gataś cāsmi C45K82K07E; gata≀ś cā≀× C94, gataś cāsmiṃ K10
 १०४ a: गतश्चास्मि C45K82K07E; गत≀श्चा≀× C94, गतश्चास्मिं K10
 104b tena dattaṃ C45K82K10K07E; ×××ttam C94
 १०४ b: तेन दत्तं C45K82K10K07E; ×××त्तम् C94
mayā dattaṃ phalaṃ tubhyam atyantasuhṛdo 'si me ||12.104|| मया दत्तं फलं तुभ्यमत्यन्तसुहृदो ऽसि मे ॥१२:१०४
104c dattaṃ corr.; datta° C94C45K82K10K07E
 १०४ c: दत्तं corr.; दत्त° C94C45K82K10K07E
 104d °suhṛdo C94K82K10K07E; °suhyado C45
 १०४ d: °सुहृदो C94K82K10K07E; °सुह्यदो C45
kuto 'nyat phalam ādāsye mama nāsti plavaṅgama | कुतो ऽन्यत्फलमादास्ये मम नास्ति प्लवङ्गम ।
105a 'nyat phalam ādāsye C94C45K82K10K07; 'nyaphala dāsyāmi E
 १०५ a: ऽन्यत्फलमादास्ये C94C45K82K10K07; ऽन्यफल दास्यामि E

sūryalokaṃ gamiṣyāmas tatra yācasva bhāskaram ||12.105|| सूर्यलोकं गमिष्यामस्तत्र याचस्व भास्करम् ॥१२:१०५

gandharvenaivam uktas tu tathety āha plavaṅgamaḥ | गन्धर्वेनैवमुक्तस्तु तथेत्याह प्लवङ्गमः ।
106b tathety āha C94K82K10K07E; tathaity āha C45

sa phalaṃ dattam evāsi suhṛdatvān mayā tava ||12.108|| स फलं दत्तमेवासि सुहृदत्वान्मया तव ॥१२:१०८

pūrvadattaphalasyārthe tac ca sarva-m-ihāgatāḥ | पूर्वदत्तफलस्यार्थे तच्च सर्वमिहागताः ।

na śaknomi phalaṃ dātuṃ kiṃ vā tv anyat karomy aham ||12.120|| न शक्नोमि फलं दातुं किं वा त्वन्यत्करोम्यहम् ॥१२:१२०

indra uvāca | इन्द्र उवाच ।

 १३७ b: मूर्तिमान्समुपासते CK82K07E; ******** K10
vauṣaṭkāro vaṣaṭkāro namaskāraḥ sa mūrtimān ||12.137|| वौषट्कारो वषट्कारो नमस्कारः स मूर्तिमान् ॥१२:१३७
137c vauṣaṭkāro vaṣaṭkāro C94C02K82E; omitted in C45, ******** K10, १३७ c: वौषट्कारो वषट्कारो C94C02K82E; omitted in C45, ******** K10, vauṣaṭkāro ca ≀sa≀tkāro K07

 137d °kāraḥ C94C45K82K10K07E; °kāra C02
 १३७ d: °कारः C94C45K82K10K07E; °कार C02
śrutiḥ smṛtiś ca nītiś ca dharmaśāstraṃ samūrtimat | श्रुतिः स्मृतिश्च नीतिश्च धर्मशास्त्रं समूर्तिमत् ।
138b °śāstraṃ samūrtimat C94C45K82K10K07; °śāstrasamūrtimān C02E
 १३८ b: °शास्त्रं समूर्तिमत् C94C45K82K10K07; °शास्त्रसमूर्तिमान् C02E
itihāsaḥ purāṇaṃ ca sāṃkhyayogaḥ patañjalam ||12.138|| इतिहासः पुराणं च सांख्ययोगः पतञ्जलम् ॥१२:१३८
138c itihāsaḥ purāṇaṃ ca C94C02K82K07; purāṇaś ca C45E, ******** K10
 १३८ c: इतिहासः पुराणं च C94C02K82K07; पुराणश्च C45E, ******** K10

āyurvedo dhanurvedo vedo gāndharva-m-eva ca | आयुर्वेदो धनुर्वेदो वेदो गान्धर्वमेव च ।
139a āyurvedo dhanurvedo C94C45K82K07E; °veda dhanurveda C02, ******** K10
 १३९ a: आयुर्वेदो धनुर्वेदो C94C45K82K07E; °वेद धनुर्वेद C02, ******** K10

arthavedo 'nyavedāś ca mūrtimān samupāsate ||12.139|| अर्थवेदो ऽन्यवेदाश्च मूर्तिमान् समुपासते ॥१२:१३९
139c arthavedo 'nyavedāś ca E; arthavedānyavedāñ ca C94, १३९ c: अर्थवेदो ऽन्यवेदाश्च E; अर्थवेदान्यवेदाञ्च C94, atharvavedānyavedañ ca C45 (unmetrical), atharvvedānyavedāñ ca C02, अथर्ववेदान्यवेदञ्च C45 (unmetrical), अथर्व्वेदान्यवेदाञ्च C02, arthavedānyavedāṃ ca K82, ******** K10, arthavedānyavedañ ca K07

 139d mūrtimān samupāsate CK82K07E; ******** K10
 १३९ d: मूर्तिमान् समुपासते CK82K07E; ******** K10
tato brahmā samutthāya abhigamya janārdanam | ततो ब्रह्मा समुत्थाय अभिगम्य जनार्दनम् ।
140ab tato brahmā samutthāya abhigamya janārdanam CK82K07E; १४० ab: ततो ब्रह्मा समुत्थाय अभिगम्य जनार्दनम् CK82K07E; **************** K10
 **************** K10
gāṃ ca arghaṃ ca dattvaivam āsyatām iti cābravīt ||12.140|| गां च अर्घं च दत्त्वैवमास्यतामिति चाब्रवीत् ॥१२:१४०
140c arghaṃ ca C94C02K82K10K07; a≀gha≀ñ ca C45, arghyañ ca E
 १४० c: अर्घं च C94C02K82K10K07; अ≀घ≀ञ्च C45, अर्घ्यञ्च E
maṇiratnamaye divye āsane garuḍadhvajaḥ | मणिरत्नमये दिव्ये आसने गरुडध्वजः ।
devarājo raviḥ somo gandharvaḥ plavageśvaraḥ ||12.141|| देवराजो रविः सोमो गन्धर्वः प्लवगेश्वरः ॥१२:१४१

vipulaś ca mahāsattva āsyatāṃ ratna-āsane | विपुलश्च महासत्त्व आस्यतां रत्न-आसने ।

sādhu bho vipula śreṣṭha sādhu bho vipulaṃ tapaḥ ||12.142|| साधु भो विपुल श्रेष्ठ साधु भो विपुलं तपः ॥१२:१४२

sādhu bho vipulaprājña sādhu bho vipulaśriya | साधु भो विपुलप्राज्ञ साधु भो विपुलश्रिय ।

toṣitāḥ sma vayaṃ sarve brahmaviṣṇumaheśvarāḥ ||12.143|| तोषिताः स्म वयं सर्वे ब्रह्मविष्णुमहेश्वराः ॥१२:१४३

yatra yatra prayāsitvaṃ tatra tatropabhujyatām ||12.146|| यत्र यत्र प्रयासित्वं तत्र तत्रोपभुज्यताम् ॥१२:१४६

maheśvara uvāca | महेश्वर उवाच ।
iti śrutvā vacas tasya vipulo vipulekṣaṇaḥ | इति श्रुत्वा वचस्तस्य विपुलो विपुलेक्षणः ।

vipula uvāca | विपुल उवाच ।
bhagavan sarvalokeśa sarvalokapitāmaha | भगवन्सर्वलोकेश सर्वलोकपितामह ।
svapnabhūtam ivāścaryaṃ paśyāmi tridaśeśvara | स्वप्नभूतमिवाश्चर्यं पश्यामि त्रिदशेश्वर ।
149c svapnabhūtam ivā° C94C45K82K10K07E; svapnamitamivā° C02
 १४९ c: स्वप्नभूतमिवा° C94C45K82K10K07E; स्वप्नमितमिवा° C02
smṛtibhraṃśaś ca me jāto buddhir jātāndhacetanā ||12.149|| स्मृतिभ्रंशश्च मे जातो बुद्धिर्जातान्धचेतना ॥१२:१४९
149f buddhir jātāndhacetanā C; buddhir jāndhacetanā K82ac, १४९ f: बुद्धिर्जातान्धचेतना C; बुद्धिर्जान्धचेतना K82ac, buddhir jātandhacetanā K82pc, buddhi jātandhacenā K10, बुद्धिर्जातन्धचेतना K82pc, बुद्धि जातन्धचेना K10, buddhi jātātvacetanā K07, बुद्धि जातात्वचेतना K07, buddhir jāto 'ndhacetanaḥ| mūḍho 'haṃ tvāṃ kathaṃ staumi jñānātītaṃ parāt param|| E
 बुद्धिर्जातो ऽन्धचेतनः | मूढो ऽहं त्वां कथं स्तौमि ज्ञानातीतं परात्परम् || E
tubhyaṃ trailokyabandho bhava mama śaraṇaṃ trāhi saṃsāraghorād तुभ्यं त्रैलोक्यबन्धो भव मम शरणं त्राहि संसारघोराद्

 कालपाशात् CK82pcK07E; कापाशात् K82ac, कालपाशान् K10
     tiryaṃ cānyonyabhakṣaṃ bahuyugaśataśas trāhi mohāndhakārāt ||12.150||     तिर्यं चान्योन्यभक्षं बहुयुगशतशस्त्राहि मोहान्धकारात् ॥१२:१५०
150d tiryaṃ cānyonyabhakṣaṃ CK82K07; tiryaṃ cānyānyabhakṣaṃ K10, १५० d: तिर्यं चान्योन्यभक्षं CK82K07; तिर्यं चान्यान्यभक्षं K10, tiryaś cānyonyabhakṣaṃ E •
 तिर्यश्चान्योन्यभक्षं E •
 °śataśas trāhi C94C45K82K10K07E; °satasa trāhi C02
 °शतशस्त्राहि C94C45K82K10K07E; °सतस त्राहि C02
śrutvaivovāca brahmā vipulamati punar mānayitvā yathāvad श्रुत्वैवोवाच ब्रह्मा विपुलमति पुनर्मानयित्वा यथावद्
151a śrutvaivovāca CK82K10K07; śrutvaiva vāca E •
 १५१ a: श्रुत्वैवोवाच CK82K10K07; श्रुत्वैव वाच E •
 °mati C02E; °matiḥ C94C45K82K10K07 (unmetrical) •
 °मति C02E; °मतिः C94C45K82K10K07 (unmetrical) •
 mānayitvā CK82K10; māṇayitvā K07, mānayaṃvā E •
 मानयित्वा CK82K10; माणयित्वा K07, मानयंवा E •
 yathāvad corr.; yathāvat CK82pcK10K07E; vat K82ac
 यथावद् corr.; यथावत् CK82pcK10K07E; वत् K82ac
     āhūtasamplavānte bhaviṣyasi tava me janmalobho na bhūyaḥ |     आहूतसम्प्लवान्ते भविष्यसि तव मे जन्मलोभो न भूयः ।
151b āhūta CK82K10K07; ābhūta E •
 १५१ b: आहूत CK82K10K07; आभूत E •
 samplavānte C02; samplavante C94C45K82K10E, saṃplavaṃnte K07 •
 सम्प्लवान्ते C02; सम्प्लवन्ते C94C45K82K10E, संप्लवंन्ते K07 •
 bhaviṣyasi C94C45K82K10K07; bhaviṣya C02, avipali E •
 भविष्यसि C94C45K82K10K07; भविष्य C02, अविपलि E •
 me janmalobho na CK82; me janmalābho na K10K07, yajanmalābhānu E •
 मे जन्मलोभो न CK82; मे जन्मलाभो न K10K07, यजन्मलाभानु E •
 bhūyaḥ CK82K10E; bhūya K07
 भूयः CK82K10E; भूय K07
garbhāvāsaṃ na ca tvan na ca punamaraṇaṃ kleśam āyāsapūrṇaṃ गर्भावासं न च त्वन्न च पुनमरणं क्लेशमायासपूर्णं
151c °vāsaṃ na ca tvan na C94K82K10K07; °vāsanna C45, १५१ c: °वासं न च त्वन्न C94K82K10K07; °वासन्न C45, °vāsā na ca tvan na C02, °vāsānubandhaṃ na E •
 °वासा न च त्वन्न C02, °वासानुबन्धं न E •
 punamaraṇaṃ C02E; punarmaraṇaṃ C94K82K10K07 (unmetrical), punarmaṇa C45 •
 पुनमरणं C02E; पुनर्मरणं C94K82K10K07 (unmetrical), पुनर्मण C45 •
 °pūrṇam C94C45K82K10K07E; °pūrṇṇa C02
 °पूर्णम् C94C45K82K10K07E; °पूर्ण्ण C02
     chittvā mohāndhaśatruṃ vrajasi ca paramaṃ brahmabhūyatvam eṣi ||12.151||     छित्त्वा मोहान्धशत्रुं व्रजसि च परमं ब्रह्मभूयत्वमेषि ॥१२:१५१
151d °śatruṃ C94K82K10K07E; °śatru C45C02 •
 १५१ d: °शत्रुं C94K82K10K07E; °शत्रु C45C02 •
 paramaṃ CK82K07E; parama K10
 परमं CK82K07E; परम K10
151d cf. Manu 1.98cd: sa hi dharmārtham utpanno brahmabhūyāya kalpate and Manu 12.102cd: ihaiva loke tiṣṭhan sa brahmabhūyāya kalpate
maheśvara uvāca | महेश्वर उवाच ।
brahmaṇā evam uktas tu viṣṇunā prabhaviṣṇunā | ब्रह्मणा एवमुक्तस्तु विष्णुना प्रभविष्णुना ।
152b viṣṇunā C94EK82K10K07; omitted in C45, viṣṇunāt C02
 १५२ b: विष्णुना C94EK82K10K07; omitted in C45, विष्णुनात् C02
evaṃ bhavatu bhadraṃ vo yathovāca pitāmahaḥ ||12.152|| एवं भवतु भद्रं वो यथोवाच पितामहः ॥१२:१५२
152d °mahaḥ C94K07E; °maha C45C02K82K10
 १५२ d: °महः C94K07E; °मह C45C02K82K10
indreṇa raviṇā caiva somena ca punaḥ punaḥ | इन्द्रेण रविणा चैव सोमेन च पुनः पुनः ।
153a raviṇā C94C45K82K10K07; ravinā C02, śaśinā E
 १५३ a: रविणा C94C45K82K10K07; रविना C02, शशिना E
 153b somena CK82K10K07; sūryeṇa E •
 १५३ b: सोमेन CK82K10K07; सूर्येण E •
 punaḥ punaḥ C94K82K10K07E; puna punaḥ C45 (unmetrical), पुनः पुनः C94K82K10K07E; पुन पुनः C45 (unmetrical), puna ca punaḥ punaḥ C02
 पुन च पुनः पुनः C02
sādhyādityair marudrudrair viśvebhir vasavais tathā ||12.153|| साध्यादित्यैर्मरुद्रुद्रैर्विश्वेभिर्वसवैस्तथा ॥१२:१५३
153c °dityair ma° C94C45K82K10K07E; °dityai ma° C02
 १५३ c: °दित्यैर्म° C94C45K82K10K07E; °दित्यै म° C02
 153cd °rudrudrair viśvebhir E; °rudrudrair viśveśvi C94K82, १५३ cd: °रुद्रुद्रैर्विश्वेभिर् E; °रुद्रुद्रैर्विश्वेश्वि C94K82, °rudrudrai viśvāśvi C45, °rudrudrai viśveśvi C02, °rudrai viśve* K10, °रुद्रुद्रै विश्वाश्वि C45, °रुद्रुद्रै विश्वेश्वि C02, °रुद्रै विश्वे* K10, °rudrair viśveśvi K07
 °रुद्रैर्विश्वेश्वि K07
aho tapaḥphalaṃ divyaṃ vipulasya mahātmanaḥ | अहो तपःफलं दिव्यं विपुलस्य महात्मनः ।
svaśarīro divaṃ prāptaḥ śraddhayātithipūjayā ||12.154|| स्वशरीरो दिवं प्राप्तः श्रद्धयातिथिपूजया ॥१२:१५४
154c svaśarīro em.; svaśarīraṃ C94K82K10K07, śaśarīro C45, १५४ c: स्वशरीरो em.; स्वशरीरं C94K82K10K07, शशरीरो C45, svaśarīra C02, saśarīraṃ E •
 स्वशरीर C02, सशरीरं E •
 prāptaḥ C45C02; prāptaṃ C94K82K10K07E
 प्राप्तः C45C02; प्राप्तं C94K82K10K07E
 154d °pūjayā CK82K10K07; °pūjanāt E
 १५४ d: °पूजया CK82K10K07; °पूजनात् E
evam ādīny anekāni vipule parikīrtitam | एवमादीन्यनेकानि विपुले परिकीर्तितम् ।
155b °nekāni CK82K07E; °nenekāni K10
 १५५ b: °नेकानि CK82K07E; °नेनेकानि K10
brahmāṇaṃ punar evāha viṣṇur viśvajagatprabhuḥ ||12.155|| ब्रह्माणं पुनरेवाह विष्णुर्विश्वजगत्प्रभुः ॥१२:१५५
155c brahmāṇaṃ C94K82K10K07E; brāhmaṇaḥ C45, brahmaṇaṃ C02
 १५५ c: ब्रह्माणं C94K82K10K07E; ब्राह्मणः C45, ब्रह्मणं C02
 155d viṣṇur vi° C94C45K82K10K07E; viṣṇu vi° C02 •
 १५५ d: विष्णुर्वि° C94C45K82K10K07E; विष्णु वि° C02 •
 °jagatprabhuḥ C94C45K82K10K07E; °jagatprabhu C02
 °जगत्प्रभुः C94C45K82K10K07E; °जगत्प्रभु C02
|| iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe vipulopākhyāno nāmādhyāyo dvādaśamaḥ || इति वृषसारसंग्रहे विपुलोपाख्यानो नामाध्यायो द्वादशमः ॥
Colophon: vṛṣasāra° CK82K07E; vṛṣa° K10 •
 Colophon: वृषसार° CK82K07E; वृष° K10 •
 °khyāno nāmādhyāyo dvādaśamaḥ CK82K10; °ख्यानो नामाध्यायो द्वादशमः CK82K10; °khyā≀na nā≀mādhyāyo dvādaśa K07, °ख्या≀न ना≀माध्यायो द्वादश K07, °khyāno nāma dvādaśo 'dhyāyaḥ E
 °ख्यानो नाम द्वादशो ऽध्यायः E









Translation




Chapter One

Invocation

|1.1| Having bowed to the One who has no beginning, no middle part and no end, whose boundaries are limitless, who is very subtle and who is the unmanifest and fine essence of the world, to the One who is wholly complete with Hari, Indra, Brahmā and the other [gods], I shall recite [the work called] ‘A Compendium on the Essence of the Bull [of Dharma]’.

The dialogue of Janamejaya and Vaiśampāyana

|1.2| Having listened to the Bhāratasaṃhitā [i.e. the Mahābhārata], the supreme book of a hundred thousand [verses] and a thousand chapters (adhyāya), with all its hundred sections (parvan),

|1.3| Janamejaya remained unsatisfied. Listen unweariedly to what he asked Vaiśampāyana in the past.

Janamejaya spoke:

|1.4| O venerable sir, O knower of the entire Dharma, O you who are well-versed in all the sciences (śāstra)! There is a supreme and secret Dharma [that causes] liberation from the ocean of mundane existence (saṃsāra).

|1.5| Teach me the Dharma that emerged from [Vyāsa] Dvaipāyana’s mouth, O best of Brahmins. Help me find satisfaction at all cost, O great ascetic!

Vaiśampāyana spoke:

|1.6| Listen with great attention, O king, to this unsurpassed narration of Dharma. Hear the secret Dharma that I received by Vyāsa’s favour.

|1.8| – |1.9| Viṣṇu, the great Lord, assuming the form of a twice-born [Brahmin], wanted to test [Anarthayajña, the ascetic yogin] who performed nonmaterial sacrifices (anarthayajña), focused on his austerities and observances, whose conduct was virtuous and pure, and who was intent on compassion towards all living beings; therefore he [Viṣṇu] humbly asked him a question.

The knowledge of Brahman

[Vigatarāga spoke:]

|1.9| How is the knowledge of the Brahman to be understood if it is devoid of form and colour? The syllable that is devoid of vowels and consonants: is there anything higher than that?

Anarthayajña replied:

|1.10| That syllable is not to be pronounced, is unquestionable, non-dividable, consistent, spotless, all-pervading and subtle: what could be higher than that?

The noose of death and time

Vigatarāga spoke:

|1.11| When the body disintegrates in the ground, in water, in fire or [is torn apart] by jackals and other [animals], how is the supportless and spotless soul led [to the netherworld] by Yama’s messengers?

|1.12| How is it bound by the nooses of death/time? And if it is bodiless, how can it move? And how does the [soul of a] virtuous [person] (bahudharmakṛt) reach heaven if it has no body? This is my doubt. Teach me. I want to know the truth.

Anarthayajña spoke:

|1.13| You are asking me about an extremely doubtful and problematic matter, O truest of the twice-born. [This is something that] is difficult to understand by humans, and [even] by gods (deva), demons (dānava) and serpents (pannaga).

|1.14| The cause of both the birth and death of the body is karma. Good and bad deeds are called the two nooses.

|1.15| [The soul] goes to hell or heaven accordingly. Happiness and suffering, both arising from karma, are to be experienced by the body.

|1.16| It is for this reason, O great Brahmin, that the human body is born. Now learn about that which they call the noose of time, I shall teach you, O you of great observances.

|1.17| [If] you don’t know anything, how could you start your investigation, O twice-born? O great Brahmin, you should know the noose of time in its entirety.

|1.18| Learn about time (kāla) which is divided into digits (kalā), [i.e. about] the division[s] (kalā) of the entity [called] time (kālatattva). Two atomic units of time (truṭi) is one twinkling (nimeṣa). One digit (kalā, cca. 1.6 second) is twice a twinkling.

|1.19| Two digits (kalā) form one bit (kāṣṭhā, 3.2 seconds). Thirty bits (kāṣṭhā) is one digit (kalā?, 1.6 minutes). Thirty digits (kalā) make up one section (muhūrta, 48 minutes) in human terms, O great Brahmin.

|1.20| Thirty sections (muhūrta) are known to the wise as night and day [i.e. a full day]. Thirty days and nights are taught by the wise to be one month.

|1.21| One year is twelve months [according to] people who know the entity of time. The time span of three hundred

|1.22| and sixty thousand years by human terms is said to be the Kali age (yuga). The Dvāpara age is known to be twice as long as the Kali age.

|1.23| The Tretā age is thrice [as long], the Kṛta age four [times as long as the Kali age]. This is the figure related to the four ages (yuga). Taking it seventy-one [times],

|1.24| the knowledge about one time-span of a Manu (manvantara) has been taught briefly. One aeon (kalpa) is fourteen manvantaras in total.

|1.25| Brahmā’s day (brahmāhar) is made up of ten thousand Kalpas. [Brahmā’s] night is of the same [duration] according to the wise who know the truth.

|1.26| When [Brahmā’s] night falls, the whole moving and unmoving universe dissolves. And when [his] daylight comes, the moving and unmoving [universe] is born.

|1.27| One para times parārdha [number of, i.e. two hundred quadrillion times a hundred quadrillion] kalpas have passed [so far], O great Brahmin. Bhṛgu and the other sages say that the future is the same [time span].

|1.28| Just as the sun, the planets, the stars and the moon are percieved in this world as wandering around, the wheel of time (kālacakra) keeps spinning and we never experience its halting.

|1.29| Time creates living beings and time destroys them again. Everything is under the control of time. There is nothing that can bring time under control.

|1.30| Fourteen parārdha [fourteen hundred quadrillion] god kings, O Brahmin, have passed by over time, for time is difficult to overcome.

|1.31| Time is [manifest] as a great yogin, as Brahmā, Viṣṇu and supreme Śiva, is beginningless and endless, is the creator, the great soul. Pay homage [to Time].

The parārdha etc.: numbers

Vigatarāga spoke:

|1.32| I have just heard [the term] ‘wheel of time’ (kālacakra) uttered from [your] lotus mouth, as well as parārdha and para. You have made these things appear as exciting, as things to hear.

Anarthayajña spoke:

|1.33| One, ten, a hundred, a thousand, and ten thousand (ayuta), a hundred thousand (prayuta), a million (niyuta), ten million (koṭi), a hundred million (arbuda), and one billion (vṛnda, 109),

|1.34| ten billion (kharva), a hundred billion (nikharva), one trillion (śaṅku, 1012), and ten trillion (padma), a hundred trillion (samudra), one quadrillion (madhya, 1015), ten quadrillion ([an]anta), a hundred quadrillion (parārdha), and two hundred quadrillion (para).

|1.35| Each should be known as powers of ten up to parārdha. The number corresponding to para is double that of parārdha.

|1.36| There is no higher number than para. This is my firm conviction, which is based on my readings of the Purāṇas and the Vedas and [which I have now] taught [to you], O great Brahmin.

Brahmā’s Egg

Vigatarāga spoke:

|1.37| How many eggs of Brahmā are there? And are its measurements available anywhere? From how many finger’s breadths high does the sun heat the earth?

Anarthayajña spoke:

|1.38| How could I enumerate [all] the eggs of Brahmā, O twice-born? Even the gods don’t know [all the details], not to mention humans.

|1.39| I shall teach [you], as far as I can, in due order and truthfully, that, O great Brahmin, which Mātariśvan was taught by Brahmā in the past.

|1.40| Ten names of all the [cosmic] rulers of each of the eight directions in Brahmā’s Egg, [which is] inside Śiva’s Egg, are being taught now, listen.

The names of the cosmic rulers

East

|1.41| [1] Sahā, [2] Asaha, [3] Saha, [4] Sahya, [5] Visaha, [6] Saṃhata, [7] Asabhā, [8] Prasaha, [9] Aprasaha, [10] Sānu: [these are] the ten Leaders in the East.

South-East

|1.42| [1] Prabhāsa, [2] Bhāsana, [3] Bhānu, [4] Pradyota, [5] Dyutima, [6] Dyuti, [7] Dīptatejas, [8] Tejas, [9] Tejā, [10] Tejavaho: [these are] the ten [rulers] in the direction of Agni [SE]. Now listen to [the names for] the Yama’s region, O twice-born.

South

|1.43| [1] Yama, [2] Yamunā, [3] Yāma, [4] Saṃyama, [5] Yamuna, [6] Ayama, [7] Saṃyana, [8] Yamanoyāna, [9] Yaniyugmā, [10] Yanoyana.

South-West

|1.44| [1] Nagaja, [2] Naganā, [3] Nanda, [4] Nagara, [5] Naga, [6] Nandana, [7] Nagarbha, [8] Gahana, [9] Guhyo, [10] Gūḍhaja: [these are] the ten associated with [the South-West].

West

|1.45| I shall teach you [the names] in Varuṇa’s region [in the west]. Listen, O Brahmin, learn from me. [1] Babhra, [2] Setu, [3] Bhava, [4] Udbhadra, [5] Prabhava, [6] Udbhava, [7] Bhājana, [8] Bharaṇa, [9] Bhuvana, and [10] Bhartṛ: these ten dwell in Varuṇa’s region [in the west].

North-West

|1.46| [1] Nṛgarbha, [2] Asuragarbha, [3] Devagarbha, [4] Mahīdhara, [5] Vṛṣabha, [6] Vṛṣagarbha, [7] Vṛṣāṅka, [8] Vṛṣabhadhvaja,

|1.47| and [9] Vṛṣaja and [10] Vṛṣanandana: these are to be known properly as the ten leaders in Vāyu’s region [in the north-west], as I taught them, O twice-born.

North

|1.48| [1] Sulabha, [2] Sumana, [3] Saumya, [4] Supraja, [5] Sutanu, [6] Śiva, [7] Sata, [8] Satya, [9] Laya, [10] Śambhu: [these are] the ten leaders in the north.

North-East

|1.49| [1] Indu, [2] Bindu, [3] Bhuva, [4] Vajra, [5] Varada, [6] Vara, [7] Varṣaṇa, [8] Ilana, [9] Valina, [10] Brahmā: [these are] the ten rulers in the Īśāna direction [i.e. in the north-east].

Center

|1.50| [1] Apara, [2] Vimala, [3] Moha, [4] Nirmala, [5] Mana, [6] Mohana, [7] Akṣaya, [8] Avyaya, [9] Viṣṇu, [10] Varada: [these are] the ten [leaders] in the centre.

Subordinates

|1.51| Each of the ten rulers has a retinue of a hundred subordinates. Each one of [these] hundred is surrounded by a thousand subordinates.

|1.52| Each one of the thousand is surrounded by ten thousand [subordinates], the ten thousand is surrounded by a multitude of a hundred thousand, the hundred thousand by a million,

|1.53| [that is] each one has a retinue of a million (niyuta) [subordinates]. [Then those] are surrounded by ten million (koṭi) [subordinates], [they in turn] by a hundred million (daśakoṭi).

|1.54| Each one of the hundred million is surrounded by a billion (vṛnda) subordinates (bhṛta). Each one in these groups of a billion (vṛnda) is surrounded by ten billion (kharva) [subordinates].

|1.55| Each in these groups of ten billion (kharva) is surrounded by a hundred billion (daśakharva). Each of those hundred billion (daśakharva) is surrounded by a trillion (śaṅku) [deities].

|1.56| Each of those one trillion (śaṅku) is surrounded by ten trillion (padma). Each of those ten trillion (padma) is surrounded by a hundred trillion (samudra).

|1.57| And each of those hundred trillion (samudra) is surrounded by those whose number is one quadrillion (madhya). Each of those quadrillion (madhya) is surrounded by ten quadrillion (ananta).

|1.58| Each of those ten quadrillion (ananta) is surrounded by a hundred quadrillion (parārdha). Each of those hundred quadrillion (parārdha) is surrounded by two hundred quadrillion (para). This is how it is taught, O Brahmin. The enumeration [of the rulers of the Brahmāṇḍa] has been taught as much as it is possible.

Measurements

|1.59| Listen to me and learn about the measurements [of the universe], O Brahmin, I shall teach [you] in a concise manner. The body of the Egg is like that of [the moon] at moonrise on the day of the full moon.

|1.60| The whole circumference of the Eggs has been declared by Brahmā to be ten million (koṭi) times a thousand times ten million yojanas.

|1.61| The Sun shines from the height of seven thousand seven hundred and twenty koṭi finger’s breath.

|1.62| The numbers pertaining to the measurements have been taught in brief. The characteristics of the unmeasurable Brahmāṇḍa[s] have been taught.

The redactors (of the Purāṇas)

|1.63| O truest of the twice-born, the Purāṇa[s of] 8,000,000 [verses] were taught by [1] Brahmā to [2] Mātariśvan [= Vāyu] in their entirety, in their true form.

|1.64| Vāyu abridged the verses and then gave [the Purāṇas] to [3] Uśanas. He [Uśanas] also abridged the verses, and [4] Bṛhaspati received them.

|1.65| Bṛhaspati taught 30,000 [verses] to [5] Sūrya [the Sun]. Divākara [= the Sun] taught 25,000 [verses] to [6] Mṛtyu [Death].

|1.66| Mṛtyu taught 21,000 [verses] to [7] Indra. Indra taught 20,000 verses to [8] Vasiṣṭha.

|1.67| And he[, Vasiṣṭha taught] 18,000 [verses] to [9] Sārasvata. Sārasvata [taught] 17,000 [verses] to [10] Tridhāma[n].

|1.68| [He taught] 16,000 verses to [11] Bharadvāja. [Bharadvāja] taught 15,000 verses to [12] Trivṛṣa.

|1.69| [Trivṛṣa] then [taught] 14,000 verses to [13] Antarīkṣa. [Antarīkṣa] taught 13,000 [verses] to [14] Trayyāruṇi.

|1.70| Trayyāruṇi, the great Brahmin, having abridged them again, taught 12,000 [verses] to [15] Dhanaṃjaya.

|1.71| Dhanaṃjaya, the great sage, handed [them] over to [16] Kṛtaṃjaya. [That recension was transmitted] from Kṛtaṃjaya, O best of the twice-born, to [17] noble Ṛṇaṃjaya.

|1.72| Then from Ṛṇaṃjaya it was given to [18] Gautama, the great sage, from Gautama to [19] Bharadvāja, from him to [20] Haryātman.

|1.73| Then [21] Rājaśravas received it, then [22] Somaśuṣma. Then from Somaśuṣma [23] Tṛṇabindu received it, O twice-born.

|1.74| Tṛṇabindu taught it to [24] Vṛkṣa, Vṛkṣa to [25] Śakti [the father of Parāśara]. Śakti taught it to [26] Parāśara, then [Parāśara] to [27] Jatukarṇa.

|1.75| Jatukarṇa taught it to [28] [Vyāsa] Dvaipāyana, the great sage. Dvaipāyana, the great sage, gave it to [29] Romaharṣa.

|1.76| Romaharṣa taught the Purāṇa[s] of 12,000 [verses], now fully revealed, to his son, [30] Amitabuddhi, for the benefit of humankind. What else do you wish to know?

Here ends the first chapter in the Vṛṣasārasaṃgraha called the Description of the Brahmāṇḍa[s].






Chapter Two

Vigatarāga spoke:

|2.1| I have heard the description of the Brahmāṇḍa from [you,] the best of men, its extent, colour, form and the numbers associated with it, in a concise manner.

|2.2| You mentioned a Śivāṇḍa as taught to be the receptacle of the Brahmāṇḍa. What are its characteristics and how much is its extent?

|2.3| Whose dwelling place is it? And [what] is the scale of the one[s] who dwell there? What kind of people live there? And who is the ruler (prajāpati) there?

Summary of the Śivāṇḍa

Anarthayajña spoke:

|2.4| Please don’t ask me about the characteristics of the Śivāṇḍa, O Brahmin. How could even the gods have the power to really know and see [the Śivāṇḍa]?

|2.5| The path leading to it is not to be trodden, it is more secret than any secret, and it is lofty. There is no master or servant there, nobody to be punished and no punisher.

|2.6| There are no truthful or untruthful people there, no moral or immoral people, no crooked people, no hypocrisy, no thirst or envy.

|2.7| There is no anger or desire there, no arrogance or discontent ([a]sūyaka), no envy or hatred, no cheaters and no jealousy.

|2.8| There is no disease, no aging, no grief and no agitation there, there are no inferior or superior people and there is nobody in-between.

|2.9| There are no privileged men or women there in Śiva’s abode, no reproach or praise, no selfish or treacherous people.

|2.10| There is no pride or arrogance there, no cruelty or trickery and so on. There are no beggars and no donors there.

|2.11| Go without material desires (anarthin), being there you’ll be resting under a wishing tree. There is no karma there and no enemy. No Kali age is there and there is no fighting.

|2.12| There is no Dvāpara age or Tretā or Kṛta. There are no manvantaras there and no kalpas.

|2.13| No universal floods of destruction come, and there are no days and nights of Brahmā. There is no birth and death there and one never encounters catastrophes.

|2.14| Nobody is tied to the noose of hope and there is no passion or delusion. There are no gods and demons there and no Yakṣas, Serpents and Rākṣasas.

|2.15| There are no Ghosts nor Piśācas, no Gandharvas and no Ṛṣis. There are no planets there, no Nāgas, Kiṃnaras or Garuḍa-like creatures.

|2.16| There are no recitations or daily rituals there, nobody performs the Agnihotra and there are no sacrificers. There are no religious observances and no austerities and no ‘animal hell’.

|2.17| Nobody would be able to tell the extent of the qualities of the god Īśāna’s powers, not even in a hundred years.

|2.18| All are born by Hara’s wish. I shall teach [them to] you one by one, excluding gods and people, starting with the trees, the bushes and creepers.

|2.19| The height [of the Śivāṇḍa] is two parārdhas, and [its] width is the same. There are lovely flowers of different forms [there] and also lovely fruits.

|2.20| There are also golden trees and also gem trees, coral gem thickets and ruby plants.

|2.21| There are tasty roots and fruits and trees with creepers on their twigs. All are shape-shifters and they fulfill man’s desires and they whisper seductively.

|2.22| There [in the Śivāṇḍa], O Brahmin, all the subjects are the oceans of endless virtues. They are all equally beautiful and strong, and they shine like millions of suns.

|2.23| [The Śivāṇḍa] is two parārdha long and two parārdha wide, and two parārdhas is its [vertical] extension, [measured] in yojanas, O great Brahmin.

|2.24| [Īśāna’s] powers cannot be expressed by numbers, neither can [His] powerfulness, O twice-born. [In fact, the distances in the Śivāṇḍa] downwards and upwards cannot be expressed by numbers. Nobody can travere it horizontally.

|2.25| [In reality,] I do not know the length and width of the Śivāṇḍa. Enjoyment is undecaying there, and there is no birth or death there.

|2.26| In the centre of the Śivāṇḍa, [creatures] shine like cow’s milk. [It is] said to be the region (ālaya) of the one and a half para crore Īśānas.

|2.27| They are all like the rising sun in the region of Tatpuruṣa. They are one and a half para crore [in number], living in the east.

|2.28| Everybody is like collyrium in the southern direction, in the region of Aghora, one and a half para crore [in number].

|2.29| In the western direction, they are like jasmine, the moon, like snowy rocks. Sadyojāta’s lovely region is [home] to one and a half para crore [people].

|2.30| In the northern direction, they are like saffron in water. Vāmadeva’s region is [home] to one and a half para crore [people].

|2.31| Īśāna has five parts (kalā), [his Tatpuruṣa] face has four. Aghora has eight, and there are thirteen Vāmadeva[-kalā]s.

|2.32| Sadyojāta has eight parts. These parts, altogether thirty-eight, which liberate us from the ocean of existence, have been taught, O truest Brahmin.

|2.33| Those who explore the truth should know the numbers, the colours and directions associated with each one [of Śiva’s faces] in the way taught above.

|2.34| If one has the intention to go to the Śivāṇḍa, one should practise Śiva-yoga regularly. Without Śiva-yoga, O Brahmin, it is impossible to go there.

|2.35| [Even] by [performing] millions of sacrifices such as the Aśvamedha, or by performing all the difficult austerities for a hundred kalpas, it is impossible to get there even for the gods, O great ascetic.

|2.36| By [merely] bathing and performing austerities at all the sacred places such as the Gaṅgā, even the honorable Ṛṣis will not be able to get there.

|2.37| Or [even] by donating the oceans of the seven islands with all their gems to a Veda expert, O Brahmin, with faith and devotion, one will not be able to go there without meditation. [This is a] certainty.

|2.38| He who destroys his own body and gives it without hesitation to those who are in need of it, or he who gives away his wife, his son and his possessions or his own head to those in need, or he who [performs] other difficult deeds, will not be able to go there [by merely doing these].

|2.39| He who has completed the sacrifices, the pilgrimages, the austerities, the donations, the study of the Vedas, will experience those enjoyments that the Brahmāṇḍa offers, still being subject to time and death.

|2.40| Dharma decays tossed forward by time. Time flies moving everything round and round like a circle of burning coal. Time is called kāla because of the waves (kalana) of the three divisions of time [past, present, future].

Here ends the second chapter in the Vṛṣasārasaṃgraha called the Description of the Śivāṇḍa.






Chapter Three

An Exposition of Dharma

Vigatarāga spoke:

|3.1| Why do they call it Dharma? And how many embodiments (mūrti) is he known to have? He is known as a bull: how many legs does it have? How many are his paths?

|3.2| I have become curious [about these questions]. Put an end to my doubts for good. Whose son is [Dharma], O best of sages? How many children does he have?

Anarthayajña spoke:

|3.3| Well, dhṛti (‘firmness’) is [of the same] verbal root [as dharma], and is said to be [its] synonym. It is called dharma because it supports (āDHĀRaṇa) and because it is great (MAhattva).

|3.4| The four-legged Bull is the embodiment of both Śruti and Smṛti. It is Dharma, as made up of the four āśramas.

|3.5| And the paths of Dharma are five. Listen, O Brahmin: [existence as] gods, men, animals, [existence in] hell and [as] immovable things [such as plants and rocks] etc.

|3.6| Eternal Dharma was born after splitting Brahmā’s heart. He has beautiful wives, thirteen in number, with nice waists.

|3.7| They are Dakṣa’s daughters, [called] Śraddhā and so on. They have huge eyes and they are beautiful. Numerous sons and grandsons were born to him. This is the emergence of Dharma. What more do you wish to hear?

Vigatarāga spoke:

|3.8| I would like to hear about Dharma’s wives truly and about each one of the sons born to them. Teach me, O great ascetic.

Anarthayajña spoke:

|3.9| [Dharma’s wives are] [1] Śraddhā (‘Faith’), [2] Lakṣmī (‘Prosperity’), [3] Dhṛti (‘Resolution’), [4] Tuṣṭi (‘Satisfaction’), [5] Puṣṭi (‘Growth’), [6] Medhā (‘Wisdom’), [7] Kriyā (‘Labour’), [8] Lajjā (‘Modesty’), [9] Buddhi (‘Intelligence’), [10] Śānti (‘Tranquillity’), [11] Vapus (‘Beauty’), [12] Kīrti (‘Fame’), [13] Siddhi (‘Success’), [all] born to Prasūti [Dakṣa’s wife].

|3.10| Śraddhā’s son is Kāma (‘Desire’). Darpa (‘Pride’) is said to be Lakṣmī’s son. Dhṛti’s son is Niyama (‘Rule’). Saṃtoṣa (‘Satisfaction’) is Tuṣṭi’s son.

|3.11| To Puṣṭi was born a son [called] Lābha (‘Profit’). Medhā’s son is Śruta (‘Sacred Knowledge’). Kriyā’s sons are Daṇḍa (‘Punishment’) and Samaya (‘Law’).

|3.12| Lajjā’s son is Vinaya (‘Discipline’), Buddhi’s son is Bodha (‘Intelligence’). Lajjā has two [more] sons: Sudhiya[/Sudhī] (‘Wise’) and Apramāda (‘Cautiousness’).

|3.13| Kṣema (‘Peace’) is to be known as Śānti’s son, Vyavasāya (‘Resolution’) is Vapus’ son. Yaśas (‘Fame’) is Kīrti’s son, Sukha (‘Joy’) was born to Siddhi. [This is how] the sons of Dharma in the [manvantara] era of Svāyambhuva [Manu] were known.

Vigatarāga spoke:

|3.14| How come Dharma has two embodiments? Tell me, O great ascetic. I am extremely intrigued. Cut my doubts concerning [this] knowledge.

Anarthayajña spoke:

|3.15| Dharma’s embodiment is said to consist of Śruti and Smṛti. The characteristics of the Śrauta [tradition] are an association with a wife [i.e. marriage] and with the fire ritual, and sacrifice. The Smārta [tradition] [focuses on] the conduct (ācāra) of the classes (varṇa) and life-stages (āśrama) which is connected to rules and regulations (yama-niyama).

Yama and Niyama rules

|3.16| Now hear the classification of both the yama and niyama rules. Non-violence, truthfulness, not stealing, absence of hostility, self-restraint, taboos, virtue, carefulness, charm, honesty: these are the ten yamas.

|3.17| The wise say that there are five subclasses to each. I shall teach you about non-violence and the other [yama-rules]. Listen carefully, O twice-born.

The first Yama-rule: Non-violence

Five types of violence

|3.18| Frightening and beating [other people], tying [someone] up, killing and the destruction of [other people’s] livelihood: violence is said by the wise who see the truth to be of [these] five types.

|3.19| Cruel people beat [other people] with sticks, clods of earth [understand: they stone them], with whips and other [objects] in the everyday world. Their bodies broken by the same blows, they receive the capital punishment.

|3.20| [Others,] tie up [people] at their feet and their arms and chests. [These,] hung by their hair and neck, die in this way without being wounded. This is the capital punishment for tying up [other people].

|3.21| He who frightens [other people] with the terrible danger of enemies and thieves, with lions, tigers, elephants or snakes, or by other horrors, will be executed.

|3.22| He who robs somebody’s money is to be punished by the same person. He is [to be] struck down by those whose livelihood got damaged by him.

|3.23| [Those who kill other people] with poison, fire, arrows, swords, or by the force of magic or yoga are called murderers by the sages who see the truth, O great Brahmin.

Praise of non-violence

|3.24| Non-violence is the highest Dharma. He who abandons it is a wicked person. It is free of pain and trouble, it yields the fruits of all [other] Dharmic teachings [in itself].

|3.25| There isn’t a bigger fool than he [who abandons it]. There is no bigger mental darkness [than the abandonment of non-violence]. There is no greater suffering or greater infamy.

|3.26| There is no greater sin or a more effective poison. There is no greater ignorance, there is nothing worse, O great ascetic.

|3.27| He who does not harm the four types of living beings beginning with plants is the best person, having compassion for all creatures.

|3.28| He who always has compassion for all creatures is the [true] Pandit. He is the [true] sacrificer, the [true] ascetic, he is the donor, the one with a firm vow.

|3.29| Non-violence is the supreme pilgrimage place. Non-violence is the highest austerity. Non-violence is the highest donation. Non-violence is the highest joy.

|3.30| Non-violence is the supreme sacrifice. Non-violence is the supreme religious observance. Non-violence is supreme knowledge. Non-violence is the supreme ritual.

|3.31| Non-violence is the highest purity. Non-violence is the highest self-restraint. Non-violence is the highest profit. Non-violence is the greatest fame.

|3.32| Non-violence is the supreme Dharma. Non-violence is the supreme path. Non-violence is the supreme Brahman. Non-violence is supreme Śiva.

On meet-consumption

|3.33| One should refrain from meat-consumption. One should not even desire it mentally. He who abandons meat will receive a great reward.

|3.34| He who wishes to nourish his own flesh with the flesh of other [beings], outside of worshipping the ancestors and the gods, is the biggest sinner of all.

|3.35| During the madhuparka offering and during a sacrifice, during rituals for the ancestors and the gods: only in these cases are animals to be slaughtered and not in any other case. [This is what] Manu taught.

|3.36| Should he buy it or procure it himself or should it be offered by others, if he eats meat, he will not sin if he first worships the gods and the ancestors.

|3.37| [People who perform] Vedic sacrifices and austerities, and [visit] sacred places, donate, [those who are of] good conduct, [perform] rituals and [keep] religious vows, [but eat meat] will not [be able to] enjoy even a tiny portion of [such rewards that] [those] people [receive] who have given up meat.

|3.38| Deer and goats, sheep, cows and other [animals] wander in the world happily and in great strength [just] from eating leaves and grass.

|3.39| Monkeys eat fruits, Rākṣasas prefer blood. The fruit-eating monkeys defeated all the Rākṣasas.

|3.40| Therefore one should not crave meat in the hope of gaining strength, O Brahmin, in order to be able to draw a bow with force, or out of fear of the danger coming from the enemy.

|3.41| By wishing to make donations and perform sacrifices no one will become comparable to someone who refrains from violence. [He will have] fame and glory in this world and the supreme path in the other.

|3.42| A person who refrains from violence will gain, no doubt about it, the [same] meritorious rewards that others would get by donating the three worlds filled with jewels and gems in their entirety to an excellent Brahmin, by [performing] a thousand [times] ten trillion (padma) [times] ten thousand (ayuta) koṭīyajña sacrifices, by donating the earth [to a priest] as sacrificial fee, and by bathing [at] a thousand times ten million times a million (niyuta) sacred places at once.

Here ends the third chapter in the Vṛṣasārasaṃgraha called the Praise of Non-violence.






Chapter Four

The second Yama-rule: Truthfulness

Anarthayajña spoke:

|4.1| The state of being real (sad-bhāva) is called truth (sat-ya). Alternatively, it is also a certainty (pratyaya) that originates in perception (dṛṣṭa). Relating things in a way that corresponds to reality is called ‘speaking the truth.’

|4.2| He who endures severe abuse and beating etc. but keeps quiet, his self being conquered, is said to be [an example of] truth[fulness].

|4.3| If one is being interrogated at any time with a sword lifted to strike him down, in this case the truth is not to be spoken, and a lie is can be called truth.

|4.4| A person who is walking on the road and is afraid of being killed CHECK should not reply [to people who are potentially dangerous] even if they ask him. This is also called truth[fulness].

|4.5| A lie does not hurt when it is connected with joking, with women, O king, at the time of marriage, at the departure from life and when one’s entire wealth is about to be taken away. They call these five kinds of lies truths.

|4.6| Since truth is the supreme Dharma in [the world of] gods, humans and animals, truth is the best, the most preferable. Truth is the eternal Dharma.

|4.7| Truth is an unmanifest ocean. Truth yields imperishable pleasures. Truth is the ship that carries you to the other world. Truth is the wide path.

|4.8| Truth is said to be the desired path. Truth is the supreme sacrifice. Truth is a pilgrimage place, a supreme pilgrimage place. Truth is an endless donation.

|4.9| Truth is morality, austerity, knowledge. Truth is purity, self-control and tranquillity. Truth is the ladder upwards. Truth is fame and glory and happiness.

|4.10| [When] a thousand Aśvamedha sacrifices and truth are measured on a pair of scales, truth indeed surpasses a thousand Aśvamedha sacrifices.

|4.11| The Sun shines because of truth. The Earth stays in place by truth. The winds blow because of truth. Water is cooling through truth.

|4.12| The oceans exist by the truthful encounter with Priyavrata. Govinda abides in truth because He [as Vāmana] stopped [Mahā]Bali [in spite of the fact that this was achieved by a trick].

|4.13| Fire burns with truth. The Moon rises by truth. It is because of truth that the Vindhya mountain stands in place and that although is was growing it is not growing [anymore].

|4.14| The [mythical] Lokāloka mountains are located in truth. Mount Meru stands by truth. The Vedas abide in truth. Dharma is rooted in truth.

|4.15| The milk a cow yields is truth. Ghee in milk is present as truth. The soul dwells in the body in truth. The eternal soul is truth.

|4.16| If truth is obtained by somebody (ekena), he/she will be one for whom Dharma is surely accomplished. By the heroism of Rāma Rāghava, the only truth was well-guarded.

|4.17| Thus have [I] taught the rules of truth to you, O virtuous one, to favour the whole world. What else do you wish to hear?

The third Yama-rule: Refraining from stealing

Vigatarāga spoke:

|4.18| I can’t have enough of learning about [this teaching of] your[s on] Dharma. Teach me further than this, O great ascetic.

Anarthayajña spoke:

|4.19| Now listen to [my teaching about] stealing, O great Brahmin, which is taught to be of five kinds. Firstly, [listen to] theft, then bribery, cheating with weights, cheating with scales, and the fifth kind, robbery.

|4.20| When somebody’s wealth is taken away by an impudent and wicked person is called theft. It is a foolish thought even if suppressed.

|4.21| O great Brahmin, listen to bribery, which defiles Dharma. A sum of money taken in order to exempt somebody from a duty is a bribe. Therefore this [also] should be considered as such [i.e. as stealing because] it is committed out of greed for material goods.

|4.22| [Even if] somebody wants to protect a family by the method of cheating with weights, that person should be considered a thief, because he takes away other people’s wealth.

|4.23| [The case is similar] if somebody takes away somebody else’s belongings by the method of cheating with scales. Other people, deceitful swindlers (kūṭa-kāpaṭika) share the characteristics of thieves.

|4.24| If someone, by deceit or by force, snatches away the wealth of weak and honest people and simpletons, that morally corrupt usurper is [simply] a thief.

|4.25| There is no sin equal to stealing. There is no crime (adharma) equal to it. There is no ill-fame comparable to that of being a thief. There is no bad-conduct comparable to being a thief.

|4.26| There is no greater ignorance than stealing. There are no bigger rouges than thieves. There is nobody as ignorant as a thief. There is not a lazy person who is comparable to a thief.

|4.27| There is nobody as detestable as a thief. There is nobody disliked as much as a thief. There is no greater suffering than stealing. There is no greater disgrace than theft.

|4.28| Some [thieves] take away [other people’s] wealth in disguise, some in broad daylight. Other wicked people take money from deposits, and some people steal through fraud. Some gather wealth by forging documents, others steal from stolen money[?]. Some people’s wealth is from purchased [children?] (krīta). Others take away others’ inheritance[?]. These are considered the vilest.

|4.29| There isn’t a bigger idiot than a thief, who is a wicked person without Dharma and Artha. As long as he lives, he trembles in fear of the king, wailing. Having received his punishment, he gets into severe and [in]tolerable difficulties, propelled by [his] karma. When his time comes, he dies and goes to hell, weeping vehemently.

|4.30| Having spent ten million ae ons of suffering, they emerge from hell to the state of animal existence. Thus, they roam about in animal existence for a hundred and one times ten million years. Then they reach the status of human existence on earth which is full of poverty and disease. Then abandoning all one’s karmas, the causes of suffering, one seeks refuge in Śiva.

The fourth Yama-rule: Absence of hostility

|4.31| The one who is hostile towards the eight-formed Śiva, he who hurts his mother or father, he who is hostile towards cows or guests: these are the five types of cruel people.

|4.32| Śiva in his manifest form (sākṣāt) is of eight forms, with the five elements (vyoman), the Sun, the Moon, and the sacrificer. [He who] disgraces [any of these] is a hostile person.

|4.33| The father is to be considered similar to the [element] sky, he is the cause of one’s birth. One should not be hostile to the forefathers, godsdots[?].

|4.34| The mother is more venerable than the earth. Who would not praise a mother? By that [praise], sacrifices, donations, austerities and [the study of] the Vedas, all will be completed.

|4.35| Cows are an auspicious blessing, they are the gods of the gods. Cows contain in themselves all the gods. That is exactly why one should not hurt them.

|4.36| Cows are the protectors of the world as if the world were their new-born [calf], there is no doubt about it. Collecting [the five products of the cow, the pañcagavya,] ghee, milk, curd, and [the cow’s] urine and dung [is auspicious].

|4.37| People who drink the five products of the cow, the five nectars, purified by the five Pavitras, will obtain the fruits of a horse sacrifice, and then reach the undecaying heavens.

|4.38| There is no wealth comparable to [having] a cow. They yield milk, they draw [a plough etc.], they roam under the sky. Feeding on grass, they issue nectar. When given to Brahmins, they deliver the family [from saṃsāra or the suffering experienced in hell].

|4.39| He who never fails to serve the cow daily [e.g. with a handful of grass], he who tends to the cows’ service, he who is kind to her [i.e. to the cow], will obtain the merits of all sacrifices, austerities and donation.

|4.40| One who looks after a guest, one who respects a guest, one who worships a guest, one who praises a guest,

|4.41| one who does not harm a guest, one who does not commit a fault towards a guest, one who keeps the guest happy, one who attends to the needs of a guest, one who makes a guest satisfied: his merits are endless.

|4.42| He should offer [the guest] a seat, a vessel with water-offering, and water for washing his feet, or gifts of food and clothes, or all [of these].

|4.43| He who worships the guest by [offering him] his own son, wife or himself with willingness, without hesitation, and with a brave heart,

|4.44| and does not ask [the guests about their] lineage, Vedic affiliation (caraṇa), studies, country or birth, and imagines mentally, with devotion, that it is Dharma himself who has arrived,

|4.45| [will obtain all the fruits of] thousands of Aśvamedha sacrifices and hundreds of Rājasūya sacrifices, a thousand Puṇḍarīka sacrifices and the fruit of [visiting] all the pilgrimage places and [performing] all the austerities;

|4.46| he whose guest is satisfied [and] he who can abandon the sentiment of cruelty, will obtain all the merits of the above, there is no doubt about it.

|4.47| dots will ever reach the path. Therefore one should go up to the arriving guest with respectfully joined palms.

|4.48| By one prastha [a small unit of weight] of coarsely ground grains given to a guest, an extremely wonderful sacrifice was performed [so to say], and his body [i.e. the protagonist in his mortal form] reached heaven.

|4.49| The mongoose related [this story in the Mahābhārata] in the past in detail, O great Brahmin, and you known it already. The story of the prastha is well-known.

The fifth Yama-rule: Self-restraint

|4.50| Self-restraint is in itself the collected essence of Dharma for humans. Self-restraint is Dharma, self-restraint is heaven, self-restraint is fame, self-restraint is happiness.

|4.51| Self-restraint is sacrifice, self-restraint is a pilgrimage-place, self-restraint is merit, self-restraint is religious austerity. If one has no self-restraint, one is a sinner (adharma), [while] self-restraint yields a multitude of desired objects.

|4.52| The elephant, the fish, the moth, the bee and the deer are without self-restraint. The senses are the skin, the tongue, the nose, the eye and the ear.

|4.53| Each of these sense faculties are hard to conquer and all are known to be fatal [if unconquered]. If one masters self-restraint in a less than proper way, one remains unrestrained and will die .

|4.54| In the case of the deer, death comes about because of hearing [when, e.g., hunters use buck grunts]. Moths die because of their eyes [as they are attracted to the light of a lamp]. Bees perish because of their smelling [as they are attracted to smells], fish because of their tongues [when fishermen feed them].

|4.55| The elephant perishes because of touch, not tolerating to be kept in fetters. How much more true it is for those who enjoy all five [senses]! Why should death come as a surprise for them?

|4.56| Purūravas [perished] by excessive greed, Daṇḍaka by excessive desire, Sagara’s sons by excessive pride, Rāvaṇa by excessive haughtiness,

|4.57| Saudāsa by excessive anger, the Yādavas by excessive drinking, Māndhātṛ by excessive desire, Nahuṣa by contempt for Brahmins,

|4.58| [Mahā]bali perished by excessive donations, Arjuna by excessive heroism, King Nala by excessive gambling, Nṛga by taking a cow.

|4.59| [For] a person who is without self-restraint, O great Brahmin, there is no heaven, liberation or happiness. O Brahmin, people without self-restraint are the destruction of knowledge, Dharma, family and fame.

The sixth Yama-rule: Taboos

|4.60| A person without taboos does not exists either in this or the other world. In a person without taboos there is no Dharma or religious austerity.

|4.61| These five should be treated as taboo: women who are not depending on oneself, others’ wealth, taking away others’ lives, hurting others and [consuming] others’ food.

|4.62| Listen, O great Brahmin, the wise should always treat women who are not dependent on oneself as taboo, [be she] a queen, a Brahmin’s wife, a wandering religious mendicant, a relative or of another caste.

|4.63| Listen further to something else, with regards to others’ wealth. [It may include] gaining wealth through unlawful means, when somebody takes away other people’s wealth by cheating with weights of one āḍha[ka] or a prastha and with scales.

|4.64| O Brahmin, the wise should regard the taking away [of others’] lives as taboo. Wild and domesticated animals, serpents, [in general,] plants and animals [are examples of life forms not to destroy].

|4.65| And what is the hurting of others? Listen, O Brahmin, I’ll tell you briefly. He who is hostile to the gods, Brahmins, gurus, mothers and guests [hurts others].

|4.66| As regards other people’s food, eating together with people whose food is not to be accepted (abhojyeṣu) is taboo, [e.g.] after birth or death [in a family], in case of vendors of alcohol, or a family having lost their caste, and in the case of a [member of the] Naṭa [caste of dancers].

|4.67| Those people who stick to the five kinds of taboo [and thus] seek heaven, wealth and liberation, will reach eternal faultlessness in this world, embellished with fame and glory. [A person like that] will obtain wisdom, intelligence, [knowledge of] the Śruti and Smṛti traditions, and honour forever. Kindness will arise and he will obtain an extra long life, no doubt.

The seventh Yama-rule: The five methods of virtue?

|4.68| The four cases of observing silence, [victory over] the four enemies, the four sanctuariess, the four meditations, and the four legged [Dharma] are called the five ways of being virtuous.

|4.69| I shall tell you about the four cases of observing silence. Listen, be attentive. One should avoid violent and slanderous [words], lies, and idle [talk].

|4.70| The fourfold enemy [made up of] desire, anger, greed and delusion is to be destroyed. He who destroys [these] enemies will become sinless.

|4.71| I shall teach you the four sanctuaries. Listen, O Brahmin. Compassion, sympathy in joy, indifference, and benevolence are the four sanctuaries.

|4.72| I shall now teach you the four meditations, which will liberate you from transmigration. Meditation is taught to be fourfold: of the Self, vidyā, bhava [= Śiva] and the subtle one (sūkṣma).

|4.73| The tattva of the Self is Dharma. Vidyā is in the five in a fivefold way[??]. They call the thirty-sixth the imperishable one, [and] the subtle tattva has no attributes.

|4.74| The four-legged one is said to be Dharma [as] it rests on the four āśramas, [those of] the householder, the chaste one, the forest-dweller and the mendicant.

|4.75| Virtuous are those who know these thoroughly, O great Brahmin. [They will experience] the purification of all sins and the growth of merits.

|4.76| One’s life-span, fame and glory and happiness grow only through virtue (dhanya). In a virtuous person piece, prosperity, tradition (smṛti) and intelligence will arise.

The eighth Yama-rule: Lack of negligence

|4.77| There are five areas of negligence. I shall teach them to you, listen. Murdering a Brahmin, drinking alcohol, stealing, having sex with the guru’s wife: they call these grievous sins. The fifth is when one is connected with them [i.e. with these sins or with people involved in these sinful acts].

|4.78| A lie concerning one’s superiority, a slander that reaches the king’s ear, and false accusations against an elder are equal to killing a Brahmin.

|4.79| Abandoning the Vedas, reviling the Vedas, being a false witness, murdering a friend, eating unfit or forbidden food are six [deeds that are] equal to drinking alcohol.

|4.80| Sexual intercourse with a female relative, with an unmarried girl, with women of the lowest castes, with the wife of a friend or of one’s own son are said to be equal to violating the guru’s bed.

|4.81| Stealing deposits, people, horses, silver, land, diamonds, or gems are said to be equal to stealing gold.

|4.82| If a man is associated with [any of these] four [i.e. brahmahatyā, surāpāna, stena, gurvaṅganāgama], he commits sin. By this all the five grievous sins have been explained. These five kinds of negligence are to be avoided, O great Brahmin.

The ninth Yama-rule: Charm

|4.83| [Charm has five types:] bodily, verbal and mental charm, [charm of] the eyes and [of one’s] thoughts as fifth. Giving [others] a friendly glance [is commendable] and one should avoid cruel thoughts.

|4.84| One should meditate with a tranquil mind and should speak [to other people using] gentle words. [When] respectable people arrive at one’s own hermitage, [one should] present them with as many gifts as one can,

|4.85| with gifts of fire-wood, water and fire. [If] fire-wood, fire and water are easily available [but] are not given [as gift] or [if the phrase] ‘Live [for a hundred years]!’ is not uttered when [somebody] sneezes, what reward could there be for such a person in the afterlife?

The tenth Yama-rule: Sincerity

|4.86| The sages who see the truth praise five types of sincerity. A sincere person does not rejoice in prosperity arising from the operation of karma or by a reward, in riches from women, from property, and bribery.

|4.87| If one is not sincere, sacrifice is in vain. If one is not sincere, austerity is in vain. If one is not sincere, donation is in vain. If one is not sincere, [sacrificial] fires are in vain.

|4.88| The sense faculties of a sincere person are firm even when he is delighted. The gods are always present in the body of a sincere person.

|4.89| Thus has been taught this section on the yama-rules, O great Brahmin. Humans should follow them to reach happiness here and in the other world. One will stand removing one’s filth of sins, and shall by Śaṅkara’s command become a ruler of the world [that he subjugates] under one royal umbrella.

Here ends the fourth chapter in the Vṛṣasārasaṃgraha called the Section on the Yama-rules.






Chapter Five

The Niyama-rules

Vigatarāga spoke:

|5.1| Now teach me the true nature of the Niyama-rules in detail. I have become desirious to hear [your] teaching that is comparable to ambrosia. Tell me more (apara vada), [to the one who had been] burnt by the fire of materiality (prakṛti), [but is now] sprinkled with the water of knowledge, and is ignorant of [the topic]. One can’t have enough of the [teaching on] Dharmas (nāsti dharmeṣu tṛptiḥ).

Anarthayajña spoke:

|5.2| I shall teach you something more that is nice to hear, O best of the twice-born. The specific sections of the Niyamas are of five types [each]. It is the essence of Dharma, dear to Hari, Hara and the sages, O great Brahmin, the destruction of the impurity of the Kali age, generally known as liberation.

|5.3| Purification, sacrifice, penance, donation, Vedic study and the restraint of sexual desire, religious observances, fasting, observing silence, and bathing: these are the ten Niyamas.

The first Niyama-rule: Purity

|5.4| From among these, now I shall tell you the particulars of purification [first], and [then] the others. [1] Bodily purity, [2] [purity of] food, [3] [purity of] property[?] (mātrā), [4] [purity of] character[?] (bhāva), and the fifth, [5]...?

Purity of the Body

|5.5| He should not beat, tie or kill [any living being]. [This and] purity concerning others’ wives and property is called bodily purity.

|5.6| The cleanliness of the ears, O great Brahmin, and of the anus, the loins, the mouth etc. [also contributes to bodily purity]. The purity of the mouth [comes from] sipping water before eating, speaking.

|5.7| After the emission of urine and fae ces, and before the worship of gods, the wise one should clean his anus and his loins with clay and water.

|5.8| One [portion of clay] for the loins, five for the anus, ten for one hand, [then] seven [portions] of clay are to be applied for both [hands] by him who wishes cleanliness.

|5.9| This is the purification for the householder (gṛhastha). It is twice as much for the chaste one (brahmacārin), three times as much for the forest-dweller (vānaprastha), four times as much for the ascetic (yati).

Purity of the food

|5.10| I shall teach you the rules of purity concerning food. Listen, pay great attention. One should eat [as much] food [that fills] two quarters [of the stomach] and drink water [that fills] one quarter. In order to give passage to the air, one should save the remaining quarter.

|5.11| [By] the wise one[’s applying] the six soft and sweet juices, [which are] the six flavours in food, the disturbances of the dhātus will disappear and the terrible illnesses will not arise.

|5.12| He should not eat what is forbidden and he should not drink what is forbidden. He should not go where he is not allowed to and he should not say what is improper.

|5.13| He should avoid garlic, onion, gṛñjana onion, mushrooms, buffalo meat and pork, following the rules.

|5.14| He should not eat chattrāka mushrooms, village hog, and cow flesh. He should also avoid sparrows, pigeons, and water-birds.

|5.15| He should also avoid [eating] geese, cranes, cakravāka birds, cocks, parrots and hawks, crows, owls, balāka cranes, fish etc.

|5.16| He should avoid everything that is ritually impure or polluted. He should also completely avoid those vegetables, roots and fruits, that are prohibited.
